issues.text: whether to a pending prosecution the provisions of the amended Code have become applicable

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision is whether to a pending prosecution the provisions of the amended Code have become applicable. There is no controversy on the general principles applicable to the case.

issues.text: whether the words in clause (c) of s. 116 'and every such enquiry or trial shall be continued and disposed of as if this Act had not been passed' mean that no provision of the Act would be applicable to pending trials

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the respondent that the following words in clause (c) of s. 116 of the amending Act and every such enquiry or trial shall be continued and disposed of as if this Act had not been passed mean that no provision of the Act would be applicable to pending trials

issues.text: whether s. 342A applies to pending proceedings before a Magistrate in which recording of evidence has begun prior to commencement of the amending Act

anchor.surface_text: High Court was of the opinion that the proceedings pending before the Special Magistrate would be according to the procedure laid down in the unamended Code and the appellant could not therefore appear as a witness under s. 342A of the amended Code.

arguments.claim: The phrase 'this Act' in clause (c) of s.116 means only some of the provisions of this Act (the specified ones), allowing other provisions like s.342A to apply to pending proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: While it must be conceded that the wording of clause (c) as also the other clauses of section 116 of the amending Act could have been put in simpler and more direct language, its ingenuous circumlocution cannot be allowed to cloak.

arguments.claim: No person has a vested right in any course of procedure; changes in procedural law operate retrospectively on pending cases unless excluded.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for decision is whether to a pending prosecution the provisions of the amended Code have become applicable. There is no controversy on the general principles applicable to the case.

arguments.claim: Respondent's interpretation of s.116(c) conflicts with the saving clause 'save as aforesaid, the provisions of this Act... shall apply to all proceedings pending... on the date of such commencement.
s.116 excludes only specific provisions in clauses (a),(b),(c),(d); other amendments like s.342A apply to pending proceedings where evidence recording began before amendment.

anchor.surface_text: The amending Act contains provisions in regard to the procedure to be applied to pending cases in s. 116 which is as follows- S.116 Notwithstanding that all or any of the provisions of this Act have come into force

arguments.claim: s.342A is in Chapter XXIV, not among excluded provisions like ss.4(2w),207A,251A,260 which relate to trial procedure; thus applicable to this case.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of clause (w) of section 4 or section 207A or section 251A or section 260 of the principal Act as amended by this Act shall not apply [...] Section 342A is in Chapter 24

arguments.claim: Under unamended CrPC, accused could not appear as witness (s.342 only for examination by court); s.342A changes this and applies here.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the High Court was of the opinion that the proceedings pending before the Special Magistrate would be according to the procedure laid down in the unamended Code and the appellant could not therefore

holdings.text: A change in the law of procedure operates retrospectively and unlike the law relating to vested right is not only prospective.

anchor.surface_text: No person has a vested right in any course of procedure. He has only the right of prosecution or defence in the manner prescribed for the time being by or for the Court in which the case is pending and if by an Act of Parliament the mode of procedure is altered he has no other right than to proceed according to the altered mode.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No vested right in procedure; cites Maxwell and Colonial Sugar Refining Co. precedent.

holdings.text: The words in clause (c) of s.116 do not mean that no provision of the amending Act applies to pending inquiries or trials; only specifically excluded provisions do not apply.

anchor.surface_text: If the whole section is construed in the manner contended for by the respondent then there will be a conflict between the words used in the various clauses and words- used in the main s. 116 and it is one of the principles of interpretation that the words should be construed in such a manner as to avoid a conflict.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction required to avoid conflict between clauses (a)-(d) and the saving clause 'save as aforesaid'; respondent's broad reading rejected.

holdings.text: The provisions of clause (w) of section 4 or section 207A or section 251A or section 260 do not apply to inquiries or trials where recording of evidence began prior to commencement, but other provisions including s.342A do apply.

anchor.surface_text: Thus construed the words of cl. c and the words of the rest of the s. 116 would mean this that the provisions of ss. 4 w , 207A, 251A or 260 of the Code as amended shall not apply or affect any enquiry or trial before a Magistrate where the recording of evidence has started prior to the date of the commencement

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of exclusions in s.116(c); s.342A in Chapter XXIV not listed among exclusions; consistent with procedural retrospectivity.

holdings.text: s.342A applies to pending proceedings before a Magistrate in which recording of evidence has begun prior to commencement of the amending Act; available to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Section 342A is in Chapter 24 and there is nothing in the amending Act or the amended Code which makes the provision of s. 342A inapplicable to criminal proceedings which are pending before a Magistrate and in which the recording of evidence has commenced. In our opinion on the plain construction of the words used in s. 116

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.342A not excluded by s.116; plain construction and harmonious reading; High Court erred in contrary view.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error; the appellant is entitled as a competent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion on the plain construction of the words used in s. 116 of the amending Act, s. 342A available to the appellant. The High Court, it appears, was misled into construing the words in clause c of s. 116 i. e. as if this Act had not been passed. The High Court was therefore in error

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.342A to facts of case; reverses lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: Section 342A is in Chapter 24 and there is nothing in the amending Act or the amended Code which makes the provision of s. 342A inapplicable to criminal proceedings which are pending before a Magistrate and in which the recording of evidence has commenced. In our opinion on the plain construction of the words used in s. 116

The High Court was therefore in error and the appellant is entitled, in our view, as a competent witness for the defence to testify in disproof of the charges made against him or any other person charged together with him at the same trial.
